title: Even Remainers think May's deal respects the referendum result, and five other charts explaining what Brits want from Brexit
text:
News Even Remainers think May's deal respects the referendum result, and five other charts explaining what Brits want from Brexit The Brexit vote has left Britain divided in how to go forward, but there are some signs that people are accepting Prime Minister May's ideas Credit: Victoria Jones/PA Patrick Scott , Data Journalists 23 January 2017 â€¢ 10:04pm 
T he Supreme Court is expected to rule on whether Parliament should get a vote on the final Brexit deal on Tuesday, as the country remains bitterly divided on the best way forward for leaving the European Union. 
Theresa May has already outlined that Parliament would get a vote, even if Brexit Secretary David Davis said it wouldn't change the outcome. 
Polling from YouGov reveals the split in public opinion over Brexit - while many are many prepared to ditch the single market, Remainers and Brexiters are failing to see eye to eye. 
Meanwhile, many still fail to understand what the Labour Party stands for in the debate as Theresa May's plan slowly gathers acceptance from all sides - even from reluctant Remainers. 
Below we list some key aspects of public opinion surrounding the debate, based on the latest polling. Majority want to leave single market to gain immigration control 
Theresa May's Brexit plans seem to be going down well with the British people. 
While Remainers are concerned about what it would mean for the economy, some 74 per cent of Brits want control over EU immigration and 57 per cent want to leave the single market and replace it with new deals. 
Leavers are predictably more in favour of these two measures - with over three quarters of them saying that leaving the single market and controlling EU immigration is the right thing to do. Chart - Brexit polling, immigration and sngle market But they're happy to back May on open Irish border and shared intelligence 
D espite the country potentially heading for a Hard Brexit , there are areas where British people think it's right to keep some aspects of their EU relationship going. 
They're happy to maintain the open border with the Republic of Ireland, to guarantee the rights of EU citizens living in Britain , and to continue to share security information. 
Even among those who voted leave, support for these three European collaborations doesn't fall below 67 per cent - with maintaining an open Irish border being the least popular of the three. Chart - brexit polling intelligence sharing The divisions between Remainers and Brexiters haven't been healed 
T hree quarters of Leave voters are set on regaining full control over how Britain is governed and who can live here, even if that means not having a free trade relationship with the EU. 
Meanwhile, 48 per cent of Remain voters think the Government should be trying to get Britain to remain in the EU altogether. A further 17 per cent think that we should be seek some form of associate membership in order to remain as close as possible to the EU. 
Despite the Prime Minister calling for unity and for both sides of the Brexit debate to come together, YouGov polling shows there's little hint of compromise on either side. Chart - Brexit polling, leavers and remainers still miles apart But they are accepting that that's what the result meant 
W hen asked if they think that May's plans respect the result of the referendum, 62 per cent of people replied positively - including 56 per of Remainers. 
They do so grudgingly, with only 28 per cent of them being personally happy with the outcome. But they still accept that May's approach is respecting the referendum result that saw 52 per cent vote for Brexit . 
When it comes to the European Union's reaction to the British approach, just one in five think that it will agree to the deal. Chart - everyone thinks Mays plan respects referendum result People don't know where Labour stands on Brexit 
42 per cent of British people are not sure what Labour's priorities are when it comes to Brexit , according to YouGov polling. 
A lmost one in five people believe that the party's strategy is to get the best possible trading links with the EU, even if that means still following some EU rules and giving up some control of our borders. 
An almost equal number of people think that Corbyn's party want to remain as close to the EU as possible and seek some form of associate membership, while 15 per cent of Brits believe it's to keep the country within the EU altogether. 
The Labour leader warned that "a Brexit that protects the bankers in the City and continues to give corporate handouts to the biggest companies is not good enough" in his New Year's message, but failed to outline any detailed plans himself. Chart - Brexit polling, Labour While America is at the front of the line in terms of Brits' post-Brexit priorities 
41 per cent of British people rank the USA as the top priority when it comes to making post-Brexit trade deals, while a further 21 per cent ranked it as the second priority when asked to rank how high a priority countries should get out of five. 
T he European Union itself is the second most-valued trading partner, according to British people's preferences, although Brexiters would favour Australia. 
Given the same ranking as the non-G7 Australia, British people said that the large economies of China, Canada and Japan should also be given high priority.
